title: How will a poet describe morning time? - Quora

response.answer_text: A poet would first strive to feel the morning time. Words can create masterpieces once put to paper; it can stir the fire on which burns the cauldron of all human emotions. I do not call myself a poet. Rather, just an emotion, waiting to be felt. So, I could probably do no justice to the scent of flowers, that I begin my day with. I cannot describe perfectly the incandescence that bid me greeting with their warm embrace. I have not the words for the feel of the kiss the dew drops leave on my lips. But, as I am such a romantic, I can imagine, with my eyes closed, a scene only Keats’ words could do justice to. Because once I give in to my senses, I can smell the smoke, hear the honks, see the traffic and feel the fire of the world, like an outraged mother waking up her ward.

Awake! For morning in the bowl of night Has flung the stone that puts the stars to flight; And Lo! the hunter of the East has caught The Sultan’s turret in a noose of light. Not mine. From good old Omar Khayyam’s Rubaiyat, brilliantly translated from the Persian by Sir Edward Fitzgerald. ———//
